Description: Egyptian terracotta figure plaque of naked woman (Aphrodite-Hathor?). Mould made and solid. Missing head and lower legs. Traces of white coating. Dark red-brown Nile silt fabric with grey core. Abundant fine gold mica, quartz, organics and white inclusions.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Simple naked female plaque figures are common in Egypt during the Late Period and in the Levant at contemporary Phoenician sites, thought examples with a child are less common. Parallels are generally dated to the Late Period and early Ptolemaic periods in Egypt and thought to be fertility figures or ex-voto in honour of, but not representing, Hathor (Török 1995, pl.109, nos 203-9, particularly no.205; Bayer-Niemeier 1988, 148, pl. 50.1-5, nos 263-7, particularly no. 264; Weber 1914, no.199; Petrie 1909, pl.35.7 and 12 from Memphis; Kaufmann 1913, fig. 69,3). Bayer-Niemeier identifies a clear ‘Pharaonic tradition’ clear with New Kingdom and Third Intermediate Period parallels from Medinet Habu (Teeter 2010, nos1 to 9 and 24 to 26) and the Temple of Mut in Luxor (Waraksa 2009, no. 3) and similar examples of this Pharaonic tradition come from New Kingdom domestic religion parallels from Deir el-Medina, Sawâma and Amarna (ibid.). Similar figure plaques found at Naukratis in the British Museum (Bailey 2008, nos 3108 to 3110; Higgins 1954, 404; GR 1888,0601.113, GR1886,0401.1543, GR 1886,0401.1458), Cambridge (NA576, NA577, NA578, NA579, NA581, NA582, NA583, NA584), and by recent excavations at Naukratis by the Supreme Council of Antiquities, (SCA), (unpublished). Similar example from the Fayum (Kaufmann 1915, no. 269). Bayer-Niemeier, E. 1988. Liebieghaus Museum Alter Plastik. Bildwerke der Sammlung Kaufmann, 1. Griechisch-römische Terrakotten. Melsungen. Petrie, W.M.F. 1909a. Memphis volume I. London, School of Archaeology in Egypt. Kaufmann, C. M. 1915, Greco-ägyptische Koroplastik. Terrakotten der griechisch-römischen und koptischen Epoche aus der Faijûm-Oase und andren Fundstätten, Cairo. Redmount, C. A. & Friedman, R. F. 1997. Tales of a Delta Site: Preliminary Report on the 1995 Field Season at Tell el-Muqdam. ‘Journal of the American Research Center in Egypt’ 34; 57-83. Teeter, E. 2010. Baked clay figurines and votive beds from Medinet Habu. Oriental Institute Publications 133, Chicago. Török, L. 1995. Hellenistic and Roman terracottas from Egypt. Roma. Waraksa, E. A. 2009. Female figurines from the Mut Precinct: context and ritual function. Fribourg Academic Press, Göttingen. Weber, W. 1914, Die ägyptisch-griechischen Terrakotten. Königliche Museen zu Berlin, Mitteilungen aus der Ägyptischen Sammlung II., Berlin.
